support_summary: As a member of the same CREB/ATF family, CREB-H (CREB3L3) can form heterodimers with the processed, active form of ATF6. This interaction modulates transcriptional activity on target genes, integrating the unfolded protein response (UPR) with other stress responses like the acute phase response.

functions.cellular_process: CREB-H (CREB3L3) is an ER-resident transcription factor that, like ATF6, is activated by proteolytic cleavage in the Golgi. The active nuclear forms of ATF6 and CREB-H can interact and form heterodimers to co-regulate target genes.
functions.effect_description: The heterodimerization of ATF6 and CREB-H synergistically activates the promoters of specific target genes, such as C-reactive protein (CRP), leading to an enhanced transcriptional response.
biological_consequence: ER stress triggers Golgi translocation and S1P/S2P-mediated cleavage of ATF6 and CREB-H → Active N-terminal fragments translocate to the nucleus → ATF6(N) and CREB-H(N) form a heterodimer → The heterodimer binds to target gene promoters → Synergistic activation of transcription integrates UPR and other stress responses
specific_effects: CREB-H and ATF6 are both members of the CREB3/ATF6 family of bZIP transmembrane transcription factors.
Both are activated by S1P/S2P cleavage in the Golgi upon ER stress.
They can synergistically activate the C-reactive protein (CRP) promoter.
Both proteins can bind to ATF6-binding elements in gene promoters.
